chapters.chapterTitle: The Vision of the Living Creatures

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 1:1-28 aloud, focusing on the description of the vision and the four living creatures.
tips: Notice the phrase 'heavens were opened' (v.1) which sets the stage for the vision
Pay attention to the repeated description of the living creatures: 'each had four faces and four wings' (v.5)
Notice the wheels: 'the wheels were within the wheels' (v.15) and the spirit of the living creatures being in the wheels (v.28)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who Ezekiel is seeing, what he sees, where it occurs, and why God revealed this vision to him in exile.
tips: Include that Ezekiel was among the exiles by the Chebar canal (v.1)
Note the four living creatures with four faces (human, lion, ox, eagle) and wheels within wheels (v.5-15)
Describe the burning coals of fire in the midst (v.18) and the glory of the LORD (v.28)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the four living creatures (v.5), the wheels within wheels (v.15), or the fire and glory (v.18-20)?
tips: The four living creatures: each face represents a different aspect of Christ (humanity, power, sacrifice, transcendence) - this is a profound revelation of Christ
The wheels within wheels: they show that God's presence is dynamic and interconnected, moving without turning (v.15-16)
The fire and glory: the burning coals of fire (v.18) represent the active presence of God, which is both consuming and life-giving

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this vision of the living creatures?
tips: The vision was a sign that God's glory is present and active even in exile (the exiles were in Babylon, but God's vision was from the heavens)
The four living creatures prefigure Christ as the one who has all aspects of God (human, divine, sacrificial, and transcendent)
This vision reassures the exiles that God is with them and His presence is unchanging (the glory of the LORD is eternal)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of the four living creatures? The wheels within wheels? The fire and glory?
tips: The four living creatures: in the ancient context, they were not literal animals but a divine symbol that represents Christ (the Christ Connection) - so it's not about four animals but about the fulln

The wheels within wheels: they are not physical but represent the movement of God's spirit (the 'spirit of the living creatures was in the wheels') - meaning God's work is in motion without disconnect
The fire and glory: the burning coals of fire (v.18) is the manifestation of God's presence, which in the temple was a sign of God's holiness and power

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the vision of the living creatures to your life this week? Specifically, how does the unity and movement of the living creatures (without turning) apply to your relationship with God?
tips: This week, try to see God's presence in your life as the living creatures (the four aspects of Christ) and pray for the strength to move without turning (in unity and purpose)
Ask God to help you be like the wheels that touch and move together (v.15) - so that your life is in harmony with God's will
Reflect on how the fire (God's presence) is both consuming (testing) and life-giving (transforming) in your life

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the glory of God revealed in this vision. Thank God for His presence and ask for the strength to see Him in the midst of your struggles.
tips: Thank God for His glory that is present even in our exile (Babylon) and for the vision of Christ (the living creatures)
Ask God to help you move without turning (like the wheels) in your life - to be in harmony with His will
Pray for the fire of God's presence to transform your life and to help you see Christ in all things

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 2:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'Son of man' and the repeated command 'do not fear'.
tips: Notice the three times 'Son of man' is used as a title (v. 3, 4, 6)
Pay attention to the phrase 'do not be afraid of their words' (v. 5) and the contrast with the 'briers and thorns' (v. 6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God commissions, WHAT he is sent to do, WHERE this commission occurs, and WHY God is sending Ezekiel.
tips: Ezekiel's role as the 'son of man' (a title for the prophet)
The Spirit's empowerment (v. 2)
The target audience: rebellious house of Israel in Babylon (exiles)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the Spirit empowering Ezekiel (v. 2), the command to not fear (v. 5), or the message to the rebellious house (v. 3-4)?
tips: The Spirit entering and setting Ezekiel on his feet shows divine authority and purpose, not human effort
The command 'do not fear' is a direct response to the fear of the rebellious exiles, which resonates with modern situations of being afraid of opposition
The phrase 'rebellious house' emphasizes the ongoing sin of the people, which is a key point for the exiles

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel's commission was to be a messenger of God's truth to a people who had rejected God, emphasizing that God's message would be known regardless of their response
The Spirit empowers the messenger to speak without fear, showing that God's authority is beyond human rebellion
This commission foreshadows Christ as the ultimate 'Son of man' who speaks to rebellious humanity

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the Spirit, the term 'rebellious house', or the command to not fear?
tips: The title 'Son of man' in Hebrew (bānāy) is used for humans but here it's a divine designation for the prophet
The phrase 'rebellious house' (v. 3) refers to the entire nation of Israel, including their ancestors, which might be confusing in a historical context
The command 'do not fear' (v. 5) is powerful because the context is a hostile environment (exiles in Babylon), so it's a challenge to overcome natural fear

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Ezekiel's commission shows that God sends messengers to rebellious people without fear. What situation requires you to trust God's message and not be afraid this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel you are the 'rebellious house' (e.g., in your relationships or decisions)
How can you practice 'not being afraid' by speaking God's truth in a situation where others might reject you?
Think about the Spirit empowering you to be a messenger in your current context

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for commissioning you as His messenger and ask for courage to speak truth without fear.
tips: Thank God for the Spirit's empowerment in your life
Pray for courage to speak truth in a rebellious world (e.g., at work, home, or church)
Ask God to help you be a 'son of man' who does not fear the opposition

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 3:1-11 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue and the symbolic act of eating the scroll.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'son of man' (v.1, v.2, v.3)
Pay attention to the contrast between the sweet scroll (v.3) and the hard foreheads (v.8-9)
The phrase 'eat the scroll' appears in v.3, which is unusual and symbolic

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is the watchman (Ezekiel), WHAT he is commanded to do (speak to the house of Israel), WHERE he is (exiles in Babylon), and WHY (to warn of judgment).
tips: Include the eating of the scroll as a symbolic act of receiving God's message
Note that the exiles are hardhearted and stubborn (v.8-9)
The watchman role is appointed by God to speak the word of judgment

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the eating of the scroll (v.3), the hard foreheads (v.8-9), or the appointment as watchman (v.10-11).
tips: The sweet scroll symbolizes God's message that is pleasing to the heart when received by faith
The hard foreheads show the resistance of the exiles, which is a warning to the watchman
The watchman role is a call to be a faithful messenger despite the unresponsiveness of the people

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel is appointed to warn the exiles of impending judgment because they have hardened hearts
The message is that God's word will be a warning to the exiles, but they refuse to listen
This passage foreshadows Christ as the faithful watchman who warns of judgment and brings salvation

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The symbolic act of eating the scroll, the meaning of 'hard foreheads', and the role of the watchman in this context.
tips: Eating the scroll is a symbolic act of consuming God's word, not literal consumption
Hard foreheads represent the unyielding nature of the exiles' hearts, which God has made the same as the watchman's
The watchman role is a call to speak the word of judgment, even when the people refuse to hear

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: As a watchman, what situation requires you to trust God's warning message this week?
tips: Identify one area where you might be 'hardhearted' and pray for God's mercy
Practice being a watchman for others by sharing the gospel message with kindness
When you receive God's word, try to remember it is 'sweet as honey' (v.3) for those who are receptive

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about being a faithful watchman and the warning message for the exiles.
tips: Pray for the strength to be a faithful watchman in your community
Ask God to soften the hard hearts of those around you
Thank God that His word is sweet and His warning is necessary

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Ezekiel 4 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 5:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the description of the barber's razor and the threefold division of the hair.
tips: Notice the phrase 'take a sharp sword' (v.1) which symbolizes God's judgment
Pay attention to the threefold division: burn, strike, and scatter (v.2-3)
Notice the small remnant 'bound in the skirts of your robe' (v.4) as a sign of preservation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe who God commands Ezekiel to do, what he divides the hair into, where the judgment takes place, and why this happens.
tips: Include the threefold division: a third burned in the fire, a third struck by the sword, a third scattered to the wind
Note that the city of Jerusalem is the target of judgment
Mention that the reason is Jerusalem's rebellion against God's rules more wickedly than the nations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the barber's razor (v.1), the threefold division (v.2-3), or the small remnant (v.4).
tips: The razor symbolizes God's judgment that is both personal and communal
The threefold division shows the severity of judgment but also God's mercy in preserving a remnant
The small remnant bound in the robe points to Christ, who comes from the remnant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about God's judgment on Jerusalem?
tips: God's judgment is severe because Jerusalem has rebelled more wickedly than the nations
Despite the judgment, God preserves a small remnant who will become the foundation for the Messiah
This shows God's faithfulness to His covenant promises

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The barber's razor as a symbol of judgment, the threefold division, or the small remnant?
tips: The barber's razor: In ancient times, hair was a sign of life; cutting it symbolized death or abandonment
Threefold division: This pattern is used in the Bible to show the extent of judgment and the remnant
Small remnant: The 'small number' bound in the robe is the church that will be preserved and from whom Christ will come

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be part of the remnant that God preserves when you face judgment?
tips: Identify an area in your life where you might be 'cut' by God's discipline
Pray to be part of the small remnant that God preserves for His purposes
Practice trust in God's provision even when the majority are destroyed

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on sin and for preserving a remnant for His purposes.
tips: Thank God for sending Christ through the remnant
Ask for courage to be part of the small remnant that God preserves
Pray for the strength to trust God's provision in the midst of judgment

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 6:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the commands and vivid descriptions of judgment.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I will' in the commands (v.1, v.2, v.3) showing God's active judgment
Pay attention to the phrase 'you shall know that I am the LORD' (v.7) as the ultimate declaration
The phrase 'scattered bones around your altars' (v.5) is a visceral image of destruction

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (the people of Israel), WHAT God does (judgment against idolatry), WHERE (the land of Israel), and WHY (to break their spiritual adultery and bring them to know God is LORD).
tips: Include the destruction of high places and altars
Note the scattering of bones around altars as a sign of God's judgment
Mention that God leaves some alive to remember Him

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the destruction of altars (v.4-5), the scattering of bones (v.5), or the declaration 'you shall know that I am the LORD' (v.7)?
tips: The phrase 'you shall know that I am the LORD' (v.7) is the climax of the judgment, showing God's purpose for the exiles to recognize His sovereignty
The image of bones scattered around altars (v.5) is a powerful visual of God's judgment on idolatry
The declaration that God leaves some alive to remember Him (v.8) shows His grace despite the judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: Ezekiel was trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon that God's judgment on idolatry would destroy the false religious practices of the nation, but He would leave a remnant who would remember Him and know that He is the LORD.
tips: The judgment is a response to the exiles' spiritual adultery with pagan gods
The purpose is to break the people's idolatry so they would turn to the living God
This passage foreshadows the need for Christ to be the true sacrifice for sin (the 'whoring heart')

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'high places', the phrase 'the slain shall fall in your midst', or the metaphor 'whoring heart'?
tips: High places were common sites of idol worship in ancient Israel and Canaan
The phrase 'the slain shall fall in your midst' means the dead (of the people of Israel) would be found in the land where they were living (the exiles' land in Babylon) as a sign of God's judgment
The 'whoring heart' refers to the heart being turned away from the one true God to worship false gods (idols)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the theme of God's judgment on idolatry and His grace in leaving a remnant apply to your life this week? Consider: What idol is in your life that needs to be broken?
tips: Think about a false god (idol) in your life that you are serving (e.g., money, power, relationships)
Practice remembering God by spending time in prayer and Scripture
Ask God to break your idol and help you know Him as LORD

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His judgment on idolatry and His grace in leaving a remnant who remember Him. Ask for strength to break idols in your life.
tips: Thank God that He is the LORD and not a false god
Pray for the courage to break idols in your life
Ask God to help you remember Him in the midst of your trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 7:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the repeated phrase 'the end has come' and the emotional tone of wrath.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the end has come' (v.3, 5, 8)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the wrath and the lack of pity (v.7)
Note the phrase 'My eye will not spare you' (v.7) which conveys the finality of judgment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the LORD and Israel), WHAT (the end has come and judgment), WHERE (the land of Israel), WHY (their iniquity and abominations), and HOW (the LORD's wrath is executed).
tips: Include the four corners of the land (v.3) as the scope of judgment
Note the specific consequences: the buyer shall not rejoice and the seller shall not mourn (v.11)
Mention the LORD's declaration of no pity and the repayment for their ways (v.7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider the declaration of the end (v.3), the lack of pity (v.7), or the buyer/seller scenario (v.11).
tips: The phrase 'My eye will not spare you, nor will I have pity' (v.7) is a powerful declaration of God's final judgment without mercy
The contrast in v.11: 'the buyer shall not rejoice, nor the seller mourn' shows the complete destruction of the community's hope and economic life
The repetition of 'the end has come' (v.3, 5, 8) emphasizes the inevitability and the finality of God's judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel was warning the exiles that the judgment of God was upon them because of their sin and the iniquity of the land
This passage emphasizes that the exiles must face the consequences of their disobedience without any hope of mercy
The main point is that the end has come for Israel, and there is no escape from the wrath of God that they have provoked

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The scope of judgment, the meaning of 'abominations', and the concept of 'the end has come'?
tips: The phrase 'the end has come' in this context refers to the final destruction of the nation, not the end of time
'Abominations' (v.20) refers to the religious and moral corruption of the Israelites, including idolatry and immorality
The phrase 'the buyer shall not rejoice, nor the seller mourn' (v.11) is a unique economic scenario that shows the total collapse of society

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of 'no pity'. What situation requires you to trust that God's judgment is coming for your sin, but you can still find hope in Christ?
tips: Consider an area where you feel God's judgment is coming (e.g., sin, failure) and how Christ's sacrifice covers it
Practically, ask God to help you face the reality of your sin without despair, knowing that Christ has already taken the punishment

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the judgment that comes on sin, and ask for the grace to accept Christ as the only hope.
tips: Thank God that Christ bore the wrath that was due to us
Pray for the courage to face the consequences of sin without hope in our own efforts
Ask God to help us understand that the end has come for the ungodly, but for believers, the end is redemption through Christ

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 8:1-14 aloud, paying attention to the description of the form with fire below the waist and brightness above (v.2).
tips: Notice the vivid description of the 'form' with fire below the waist and brightness above (v.2)
Pay attention to the words 'abominations' (v.3) and the specific acts of idolatry described (vv.4-14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is transported, WHAT God commands, WHERE it takes place, and WHY Ezekiel sees this.
tips: Include the three key events: the vision of the abominations (v.3-14), the seventy elders offering incense to idols (v.4), and the women weeping for Tammuz (v.5)
Note that the twenty-five men are worshiping the sun (v.8) and the temple is defiled (v.3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the form with fire and brightness (v.2), the women weeping for Tammuz (v.5), or the twenty-five men worshiping the sun (v.8)?
tips: The form with fire and brightness (v.2) shows God's holy presence being revealed in the midst of sin
The women weeping for Tammuz (v.5) demonstrates the deep spiritual crisis of the exiles
The twenty-five men worshiping the sun (v.8) is a clear act of idolatry that the temple was defiled with

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon about the hidden idolatry in the temple?
tips: Ezekiel reveals that the temple was defiled by secret idolatry, which the exiles were committing even in the temple
This vision shows that the people's hidden sins (idolatry) are causing the temple to become a place of abominations
Christ connection: Jesus cleansed the temple (John 2:13-22) from these hidden idolatries

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'image of jealousy' (v.3), the cultural practice of weeping for Tammuz (v.5), and the sun worship (v.8)?
tips: The 'image of jealousy' (v.3) refers to the idol that the people are worshiping, which causes the temple to be defiled
Tammuz was a Babylonian deity, and the weeping for him shows a cultural practice of mourning that the exiles were adopting
Sun worship (v.8) was a common practice in ancient Babylon, but the temple was supposed to be a place of the one true God

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, examine your heart: Are there hidden idolatry (things you worship more than God) that you need to address?
tips: Consider the temple of your heart: Is it defiled with secret sins or idolatry?
Pray for the strength to confront and remove idols from your life
Read 1 John 5:16-17 about hidden sins

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God to reveal hidden idolatry in your life and the temple of your heart.
tips: Thank God that He sees the hidden sins of your heart
Ask for the courage to confront and remove idols from your life
Pray for the strength to live in the temple of God without idolatry

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 9:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the command to summon the executioners and the marking of foreheads.
tips: Notice the sudden command: 'Bring near the executioners' (v.1)
Pay attention to the man in linen with the writing case (v.3)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved (the executioners, God, the people), WHAT happens (the marking and slaughter), WHERE it takes place (Jerusalem), and WHY (judgment on idolaters).
tips: Include the six executioners summoned from the upper gate
Note the man in linen who marks the foreheads of those who 'sigh and groan' over idolatry
Describe the executioners striking without sparing, starting at the sanctuary

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the marking of the foreheads (v.4), the command to strike without sparing (v.5), or the remnant being protected (v.6-7)?
tips: The phrase 'men who sigh and groan over all the abominations' (v.4) shows the city's internal lament — this is the group God chooses to save
The command: 'Your eye shall not spare' (v.5) is shocking — it's a direct call for total destruction
The mark on the forehead (v.4) is a direct parallel to the Passover blood that saves

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about the coming judgment and the remnant?
tips: Ezekiel warns that God's judgment on Jerusalem (for idolatry) is imminent, but a remnant will be spared through faith in God's mark
This prophecy points to Christ: the mark is the blood of Christ that protects from the angel of destruction

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The executioners' role, the meaning of the mark, or the scope of the judgment?
tips: Why does God choose to mark only those who 'sigh and groan'? This is a sign of genuine repentance in the city (v.4)
The phrase 'begin at My sanctuary' (v.5) indicates that the judgment starts at the temple — a common place of worship for idolatry
The man in linen with the writing case: This is likely a scribe (like a prophet) who records the mark — showing the divine authority

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage apply to your life? Think about being marked by God's grace and the cost of obedience.
tips: Consider an area where you feel like you are 'sighing and groaning' over sin or idolatry in your life
Pray for the mark of God's grace to be written on your heart (like the Passover blood)
Make a decision to 'strike' your sin (like the executioners) — but only the sins that are covered by Christ's blood

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the remnant and ask for the mark of His grace.
tips: Thank God that He has a remnant of people who are spared from the destruction
Pray for courage to be marked by Christ's blood (the blood of the Lamb) in your life
Ask God to help you see the 'abominations' in your life that need to be addressed

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 10:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the description of the sapphire throne and the movement of the glory.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the glory of the LORD' (v.5, v.15)
Pay attention to the sound of the wings of the cherubim (v.5) as a sign of divine power
Note the transition from the glory being in the court to the threshold and then departing (v.5, v.15)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize who is involved, what happens, where it takes place, and why it matters for the exiles in Babylon.
tips: Include the vision of the sapphire throne above the cherubim (v.1)
Note the man in linen going to the wheels (v.2)
Describe the glory moving from the cherubim to the threshold (v.5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the glory of the LORD moving from the cherub to the threshold (v.5), the sound of the wings (v.5), or the cherubim lifting up and moving (v.17)?
tips: The glory moving from the cherubim to the threshold (v.5) shows God's presence leaving the temple but still present in the court
The sound of the wings of the cherubim (v.5) is a powerful sign of God's active presence
The cherubim lifting up and moving (v.17) symbolizes the temple's destruction and the people being taken away

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon through this vision of the glory departing?
tips: This vision shows that the glory of God (the temple) is being destroyed, but God's presence remains with His people through Christ
Ezekiel is warning the exiles that the temple is no longer the dwelling place of God, but the new covenant (Christ) will be the true temple
The glory never departs from God's people because Christ is the new temple

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The departure of the glory? The role of the cherubim and wheels? The connection to the temple's destruction?
tips: The 'glory' in this context is the visible manifestation of God's presence in the temple; its departure foreshadows the temple's destruction (586 BC)
The cherubim and wheels are a symbol of the temple's structure; in this vision, they move as the glory departs, indicating the temple is being dismantled
The passage does not explicitly say the temple is destroyed, but the vision of the glory leaving is a sign that the old covenant is ending

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the passage's theme that God's glory never departs from His people (through Christ) apply to your life this week?
tips: Pray for the assurance that Christ is the new temple where God's glory dwells
Share your anxiety about the 'glory' leaving your life with a friend, knowing that Christ remains
Spend time in prayer asking God to show you where He is present in your life (the new temple)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's presence in your life as the new temple (Christ) where His glory never departs.
tips: Thank God that He is the temple where His glory dwells
Ask for the courage to trust that the glory of God is with you in Christ
Pray for the strength to see God's presence in the midst of trials

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 11:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Ezekiel and the Spirit in verses 5-6 and the death of Pelatiah in verse 10.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the city is the cauldron' (v.6) which is a powerful image of God's judgment
Pay attention to the death of Pelatiah (v.10) as a sign of God's judgment
The phrase 'I will bring you out of the midst of it' (v.6) appears twice in the chapter (v.6 and v.10) - note the repetition

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being judged, WHAT they are doing, WHERE this happens, and WHY God is acting.
tips: Include the 25 men at the gate (v.3) who are wicked counselors
Note the cities of the exiles in Babylon (v.4) as the 'cauldron'
Describe God's judgment on Pelatiah (v.10) and the promise of a new heart (v.20)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the image of the cauldron (v.6), Pelatiah's death (v.10), or the promise of a new heart (v.20)?
tips: The image of the city as the cauldron and the people as meat (v.6) is a vivid metaphor for God's judgment on the unfaithful
Pelatiah's death (v.10) happens right as Ezekiel prophesies, showing God's immediate judgment on the wicked
The promise of a new heart and new spirit (v.20) offers hope beyond the judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon about the wicked leaders and God's judgment?
tips: Ezekiel is warning the exiles that their leaders are corrupt and will be judged by God
The promise of a new heart (v.20) shows God's plan to restore the exiles through the Holy Spirit
This passage points to the need for spiritual renewal in the midst of Babylonian exile

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The image of the cauldron (v.6), why Pelatiah dies (v.10), or the promise of a new heart (v.20)?
tips: The phrase 'the city is the cauldron' (v.6) is a metaphor for God's judgment: the city is being used as a place of destruction, and the people are the food for the fire
Pelatiah's death (v.10) is a sudden event that shows God's direct judgment on the wicked leaders, not a natural death
The promise of a new heart (v.20) is a spiritual transformation that comes through God's action, not human effort

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of a new heart (v.20) to your life this week? What area of your life needs God's new spirit?
tips: Identify one area where you are acting as a 'wicked counselor' (e.g., unfaithful leadership in your church or family)
Ask God to give you a new heart for the area where you are struggling (e.g., forgiveness, humility)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to transform your heart as described in v.20

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on wicked leaders and ask for a new heart.
tips: Thank God for the judgment on the unfaithful leaders in your life
Ask for the Holy Spirit to give you a new heart and new spirit (v.20)
Pray for the exiles (the church) to be restored through God's promise

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 12:1-12 aloud, focusing on the actions of preparing for exile and the physical act of going into exile.
tips: Notice the phrase 'in their sight' appears multiple times to show the public nature of the sign
Pay attention to the sequence: prepare by day, go out at evening, dig through the wall, carry baggage out at dusk
Note the covering of the face as a symbol of not seeing the land (the city)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Ezekiel) does WHAT (acts as a sign of exile), WHERE (in the midst of the rebellious house in Babylon), and WHY (to show the exiles that their rebellion has led to exile).
tips: Include the detail that Ezekiel prepares his baggage by day
Note that he goes out at evening as an exile
Describe how he carries the baggage out at dusk and covers his face

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the preparation of baggage (v.1-2), the act of going out (v.3-4), the covering of the face (v.12), or the significance of the sign (v.10-11)?
tips: The phrase 'in their sight' emphasizes that Ezekiel's actions are visible to the exiles as a public sign
The act of covering the face to not see the land shows a deliberate turning away from the home the exiles had rebelled against
The sequence of actions (preparing by day, going at evening, carrying out at dusk) mirrors the timing of the exile itself

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel is showing that the house of Israel has been rebellious and will face exile (as a sign of God's judgment)
The exile is a sign that the exiles must see their own blindness and rebellion
This passage foreshadows the ultimate exile of Israel in the New Testament (the cross as the ultimate sign)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'in their sight', the physical act of digging through the wall, or the covering of the face?
tips: 'In their sight' refers to the public, visible nature of the sign for the exiles to witness
Digging through the wall is a metaphor for the exiles' own separation from their homeland
Covering the face is a symbol of turning away from the land of rebellion and the blindness of the house of Israel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Ezekiel's action of preparing for exile and covering his face shows a turning away from what is familiar. What area of your life requires you to turn away from and embrace exile (as in, surrender to God's plan) this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are holding on to something that is causing you to be blind to God's will
Think about how you can 'cover your face' by not focusing on the past or current struggles that blind you to the future
Practice the discipline of preparing for the next step (like carrying your baggage) even when it's not immediately visible

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He uses signs to show us our exile (blindness) and the need for Him to open our eyes. Ask for the strength to turn away from our blindness and embrace His plan.
tips: Thank God for the sign of exile that shows the rebellion of the house of Israel
Pray for the eyes of understanding to open the blind spots in your life
Ask for the courage to carry your 'baggage' (your burdens) out into exile as God's plan unfolds

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Note the repetition of 'false visions' (v. 2, 6, 10)
Pay attention to the image of 'jackals among ruins' (v. 2) for destruction
Notice the phrase 'whitewashed wall' (v. 10) that will fall

tips: Ezekiel (the prophet) addresses the false prophets of Israel
They give false visions and lying divinations
This occurs in the context of the exiles in Babylon

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of false prophets as 'jackals among ruins' (v. 2), the phrase 'peace when there is no peace' (v. 10), or the 'whitewashed wall' (v. 10).
tips: The jackal image shows false prophets are destructive and blind
The phrase 'peace when there is no peace' highlights the deception in false peace
The whitewashed wall that falls illustrates how false teachings appear good but are actually destructive

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon about false prophets?
tips: Ezekiel warns that false prophets are dangerous because they lead the people astray
He calls for the exiles to avoid false teachings and trust the true word of God
This passage emphasizes that God will judge false prophets and protect His people from deception

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? How does 'jackals among ruins' relate to false prophets? What does 'whitewashed wall' mean? Why does God say false prophets 'smear' the wall?
tips: Jackals among ruins (v. 2) is a metaphor for false prophets who are destructive and blind to the truth
Whitewashed wall (v. 10) means false teachings that seem good but are actually weak and will collapse
Smearing the wall (v. 10) refers to false prophets making the people's defenses look strong but they are actually ineffective

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you avoid the 'whitewashed wall' of false teaching in your life this week?
tips: Check your beliefs against the true word of God
Ask if your 'peace' is real or just an illusion
Spend time in Scripture to build a strong foundation that won't fall

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Lord, help us to see the false prophets in our lives and in the world. Guide us to seek Your true word.
tips: Thank God for His truth that protects us from false teachings
Pray for wisdom to discern false prophets
Ask God to give us courage to stand for truth when it's hard

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 14:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'stumbling block of iniquity' (v. 4) and the list of four judgments (v. 15).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'idols' (v. 3, 4, 6) and 'stumbling block' (v. 4)
Pay attention to the emotional weight of the phrase 'even if Noah, Daniel, and Job were in it' (v. 14)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO the Lord addresses, WHAT they are doing, WHERE this is happening, and WHY the Lord is calling them to repentance.
tips: The elders of Israel (exiles in Babylon) have taken idols into their hearts (v. 3)
The Lord commands them to repent and turn away from idols (v. 6)
This happens in the context of the exiles in Babylon (v. 1)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the reference to Noah, Daniel, and Job (v. 14), the four judgments (v. 15-16), or the call to repent (v. 6).
tips: The statement about Noah, Daniel, and Job shows that even the greatest righteous men cannot save the people from God's judgment if they are in idolatry (v. 14)

The call to repent (v. 6) is urgent and personal: 'Repent and turn away from your idols'

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon through this passage about idolatry?
tips: The exiles were living in idolatry (taking idols into their hearts) and needed to repent to avoid the four judgments
Even the most righteous (like Noah, Daniel, Job) cannot save the people from God's judgment if they are in idolatry
The only hope is repentance and turning away from idols

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to Noah, Daniel, and Job? The meaning of 'stumbling block'? The four judgments?
tips: 'Noah, Daniel, and Job' are used to show that even the most righteous cannot save the people from God's judgment if they are in idolatry (v. 14)
'Stumbling block of iniquity' refers to the sin that leads to a fall (v. 4)
The four judgments (sword, famine, wild beasts, pestilence) are specific consequences of idolatry that will come upon the land (v. 15-16)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of idolatry in your heart this week? Identify one idol and commit to turning away from it.
tips: Reflect on what you have taken into your heart (e.g., habits, relationships, thoughts) that are causing you to stumble
Pray for the strength to turn away from that idol and seek God's help
Write down one step to remove an idol this week

tips: Thank God for His judgment on idolatry and His mercy to those who repent
Pray for the courage to turn away from idols in your heart
Ask God to help you identify and remove one idol this week

chapters.chapterTitle: The Soul Who Sins Shall Die

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 18:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the old proverb and the new teaching.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the soul who sins shall die' (v.4) and the contrast with the father's sin not being inherited (v.20)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from the old proverb (which is about inheritance of sin) to the new teaching of individual responsibility (v.21-22)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being addressed, WHAT the LORD says about sin and death, WHERE this teaching takes place (in the context of Babylon), and WHY it matters to the exiles.
tips: Include the contrast between the old proverb (fathers eating sour grapes) and the new teaching of individual responsibility
Note the two examples: the righteous man who lives and the man who does not live because of his son's sin
The call for repentance and the promise of a new heart

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the contrast between the father's sin and the son's choice (v.20), the promise of a new heart (v.31), or the call to 'repent and live' (v.33)?
tips: The phrase 'the soul who sins shall die' (v.4) is stark and direct, emphasizing personal accountability
The son who sees his father's sins but does not follow them (v.20) shows the possibility of redemption
The promise of a new heart (v.31) is a powerful image of God's transformative power

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon about individual responsibility and repentance?
tips: Ezekiel is challenging the exiles' belief in inherited sin to show that each person is responsible for their own actions
He is calling for a personal turn to God, not a collective punishment
This passage is a theological correction to the prevailing culture of Israel (where sin was seen as inherited)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The concept of 'soul' (heb: nephesh), the meaning of 'repent and live', or the idea that the son is not responsible for the father's sin?
tips: 'Soul' (nephesh) in Hebrew refers to the living being, not just the physical body; it emphasizes the whole person
'Repent and live' (v.33) is a call to change one's heart and behavior, not just a temporary feeling
The exiles in Babylon had a culture of inherited sin (like the old proverb), so Ezekiel is breaking that pattern

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The passage emphasizes that we are responsible for our own choices. What area of your life requires you to make a new choice this week?
tips: Consider a habit or decision that you've been repeating without reflection
Think about how you can 'cast away' your old patterns and 'make a new heart' (v.31)
Pray for the strength to choose righteousness over sin

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about the theme of individual responsibility and the call to repentance. Ask for God's help to live righteously.
tips: Thank God for His clear standard of righteousness
Ask for the courage to repent when you've sinned
Pray for a new heart that desires to obey God

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 19:1-10 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the lament and the repetition of phrases about the cubs and the vine.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'he became a young lion' (vv. 4, 6)
Pay attention to the phrase 'the nations heard about him' (v. 4) and 'the nations set against him' (v. 8) to see the theme of opposition
Note the contrast between the vine's former state ('fruitful and full of branches') and its current state ('planted in the wilderness')

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is lamented, WHAT happened to the princes, WHERE the destruction occurred, and WHY the lament is necessary.
tips: Include the two kings (cubs) who were captured: the first taken to Egypt and the second to Babylon
Note the vine of Israel that was once fruitful but now is in the wilderness
Describe the lament as a response to the failure of God's chosen leadership

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lioness (mother of Israel) rearing cubs, the first king's capture, or the vine being plucked up.
tips: The image of the lioness rearing cubs shows God's care for Israel's leadership (princes) who were meant to rule
The first king being 'caught in his pit' (v. 4) illustrates the destruction of the kingdom's first line of leadership
The vine being 'plucked up in fury' (v. 10) is a powerful metaphor for the sudden and violent end of the kingdom

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about the failure of Israel's princes and the hope for restoration?
tips: Ezekiel lamented the destruction of God's chosen kingdom (the vine) and the failure of its leaders (princes)
This passage points to the need for repentance and the promise of future restoration through Christ
The exiles were reminded that their hope must come from God's covenant, not their own strength

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this passage are challenging to understand? Consider cultural context, Hebrew terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The term 'princes' refers to the rulers of Judah who were destroyed by Babylon, but the passage uses a metaphor of a lioness to show God's care for the kingdom
The phrase 'plucked up in fury' (v. 10) describes the violent destruction of the kingdom by Babylonian conquest
The two cubs represent two lines of kings (the first being the kings of Judah and the second being the new generation) who both failed

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of lamentation and hope in your life this week? Specifically, what situation requires you to trust God's provision like the vine that will be planted again?
tips: Reflect on a time when you felt like you were 'plucked up in fury' (like the vine) and how God is still working
Pray for the courage to trust God when you feel like you are in the wilderness (dry and thirsty land)
Ask God to help you be like the lioness who rears cubs (leaders) by nurturing others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the exiles in Babylon and for your own life in light of this lament. Ask for God's strength to trust in His provision.
tips: Thank God for His covenant with Israel and His promise of restoration through Christ
Pray for the courage to trust God when things seem lost (like the vine in the wilderness)
Ask the Holy Spirit to help you be a 'lioness' who rears cubs (leaders) in your community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 20:1-26 aloud, paying attention to the repetition of God's oath (v. 11) and the specific examples of idolatry (v. 13, 20).
tips: Notice the phrase 'I chose Israel' (v. 11) is repeated to emphasize God's initial covenant
Pay attention to the description of idolatry: 'detestable things' (v. 13) and 'offer up your children' (v. 20)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO God addresses, WHAT He reveals about Israel's rebellion, WHERE this rebellion occurred historically, and WHY He is reviewing it.
tips: Include the exiles in Babylon as the current audience
Note the rebellion from Egypt (v. 11) to the wilderness (v. 12) and the consequences
Highlight God's action for His name's sake (v. 10) despite their rebellion

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: God's oath in Egypt (v. 11), the wilderness rebellion (v. 15), or the promise of gathering (v. 37)?
tips: The phrase 'I led them out of the wilderness' (v. 15) shows God's active care despite their rebellion
The promise 'I will gather you from the peoples with a mighty hand' (v. 37) is a powerful hope for the exiles
The contrast between their idolatry and God's faithfulness (v. 16) is poignant

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about God's covenant with Israel through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel emphasizes that God's covenant with Israel is unbroken, even when they rebel
He shows that God acts for His name's sake (v. 10) - meaning He does what is necessary to maintain His reputation
The promise of gathering (v. 37) addresses the exiles' current situation in Babylon

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The scope of rebellion, the meaning of 'for My name's sake', or the promise of gathering?
tips: 'Detestable things' (v. 13) refers to idolatry and pagan practices that were common in Egypt and Canaan
'Offer up your children' (v. 20) is a specific form of idolatry that was practiced in the ancient Near East
'For My name's sake' (v. 10) means God acts to maintain His reputation and authority, not to be 'inquired of' by the rebellious

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the promise of God gathering His people (v. 37) to your current situation this week?
tips: Identify a specific area where you feel 'scattered' (like the exiles) and pray for God's gathering
Avoid the 'detestable things' (v. 13) by staying away from idolatry in your life
Act in a way that honors God's name (v. 10) by being faithful in small ways

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray: Thank God for His faithfulness despite Israel's rebellion. Ask for the strength to be gathered by His hand and to avoid idolatry.
tips: Thank God for gathering us from the nations (v. 37) as we are part of His people
Pray for courage to resist idolatry (v. 13) in our modern context
Ask God to help us live for His name's sake (v. 10)

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 21:1-27 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of the sword being drawn and the king of Babylon's divination practices.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'I have drawn My sword from its sheath' (v. 22)
Pay attention to the contrast between the LORD's judgment and the king's divination (v. 20-21)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO the LORD is targeting, WHAT He does, WHERE it happens, and WHY He is acting.
tips: Include the LORD's judgment on both righteous and wicked (v. 22)
Note the king of Babylon at the crossroads of two paths (v. 20)
Describe the removal of the crown (v. 27)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the sword being drawn (v. 22), the king of Babylon's divination (v. 20-21), or the removal of the crown (v. 27).
tips: The phrase 'I have drawn My sword from its sheath' (v. 22) is a powerful image of God's active judgment
The king of Babylon consulting divination (v. 20-21) shows the contrast between idolatry and God's true judgment
The removal of the crown (v. 27) points to Christ as the rightful king who will restore the kingdom

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to the exiles in Babylon through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel warns that God's judgment is coming on the entire nation (righteous and wicked) to show that no one is safe
The passage points to Christ as the one who will restore the kingdom (v. 27) and replace the Babylonian king
This prophecy serves as a reminder that God's sovereignty is absolute and His judgment is inevitable

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The king of Babylon's role in divination? The meaning of the crown removal? The sword being drawn?
tips: The term 'teraphim' (v. 20) refers to household idols used for divination in ancient Near East cultures
The phrase 'the crown is removed' (v. 27) does not mean the king of Babylon is deposed immediately, but rather that the kingdom of Babylon is temporary and Christ is the true king
The sword being drawn (v. 22) is a symbol of God's active judgment against the entire nation, not a metaphor for a specific event

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's judgment and the coming of Christ to your life this week?
tips: When you face a crisis or difficult situation, pray for the strength to trust that God is in control (like the sword being drawn but not for destruction, but for restoration)
Reflect on the exiles' hope in Christ as the one who will restore the kingdom (v. 27)
Practice surrendering to God's plan when you feel the 'sword' of judgment is near

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of God's judgment and the hope in Christ.
tips: Thank God that He is the LORD who draws His sword and will restore His people
Pray for courage to trust in Christ as the one who will bring the kingdom
Ask God to strengthen your heart to face the 'sword' of judgment with hope in His restoration

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 22:1-22 aloud, paying attention to the list of sins and the absence of an intercessor.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'you' in the list of sins (vv. 1-22) to emphasize collective guilt
Pay attention to the phrase 'bloody city' (v. 1) and 'defiled' (v. 2) to understand the severity of the sin
Notice the contrast between the city's sins and the lack of one to stand in the breach (v. 28)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is judged, WHAT the city has done, WHERE this judgment is happening (the city of Jerusalem), and WHY the judgment is coming.
tips: Include the list of sins: bloodshed, idolatry, contempt for parents, extortion of sojourners, wronging the fatherless and widow
Note that the city has profaned God's holy things and Sabbaths
The result: no one found to stand in the breach (v. 28)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the city's comprehensive sins (v. 25), the princes like wolves (v. 26), or the absence of an intercessor (v. 28)?
tips: The description of the city as 'bloody' (v. 1) shows the depth of sin and the need for immediate action
The princes being 'like wolves tearing the prey' (v. 26) is a vivid image of corruption in leadership
The absence of one to stand in the breach (v. 28) is a powerful call for the community to see the need for a true intercessor

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about the sins of Jerusalem?
tips: Ezekiel is warning the exiles that the sins of Jerusalem are so severe that God will not save the city without repentance
The exiles are to see that their own sinfulness mirrors the city's sin, so they must repent
This passage foreshadows Christ as the one who stands in the breach (v. 28) for the city of God

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The list of sins, the meaning of 'whitewash', or the concept of 'standing in the breach'?
tips: 'Bloody city' refers to the city's sin of bloodshed and violence, not just physical blood
'Whitewash' (v. 27) means false prophets who cover up the sins with empty words but the reality is corruption
'Standing in the breach' (v. 28) is a metaphor for intercession or repair, but the city has no one who is genuine

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you be a 'builder of the wall' in your community this week?
tips: Identify one area where you are part of the 'bloodshed' (e.g., unkind words, injustice) and seek to repent
Ask God to help you stand in the breach for others who are vulnerable (like the fatherless or widow)
Pray for a community that is willing to build up the wall together

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the exiles in Babylon and for the city of Jerusalem (and our lives) to see the need for repentance and intercession.
tips: Thank God for His judgment on sin and His provision of Christ as the true intercessor
Pray for courage to confront sin in your community
Ask God to help us build the wall of community and faith

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Ezekiel 23:1-30 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the two sisters and the progression of their unfaithfulness.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'whore' and 'adultery' to emphasize spiritual unfaithfulness
Pay attention to the contrast between Oholah (Samaria) and Oholibah (Jerusalem)
Emotional tone: The passage is a severe judgment but also a call for redemption

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is unfaithful, WHAT they did, WHERE it happened (in terms of the two cities), and WHY God is judging them.
tips: Include the two sisters: Oholah (Samaria) and Oholibah (Jerusalem)
Note the key event: both engaged in spiritual adultery with Assyrians and Chaldeans
Why: Because they turned away from God and worshipped false gods

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel's main message to the exiles in Babylon?
tips: God's desire for the people to turn from their evil ways and live, not to die in sin
The watchman (prophet) has a responsibility to warn, but the people must heed the warning
This message applies to all people today: God wants us to turn from sin and live

The responsibility of the watchman: How does it apply to the people? (The watchman is the one who must warn, but the people are responsible for heeding)

questions.title: Application

tips: Identify one area where you have been ignoring God's warnings (e.g., sin, lack of faith)

Be a watchman for others: warn them of sin when you see it

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray about God's desire for the wicked to turn and live.
tips: Thank God that He desires for us to turn and live, not die
Ask for the courage to be a watchman (to warn others and yourself)
Pray for the exiles in Babylon (the church today) to turn from their evil ways

tips: The phrase 'I will search for My sheep' (v.10) shows God's personal and active care for the lost

questions.title: Main Point

tips: Ezekiel was addressing the exiles who had been neglected by corrupt religious leaders (the shepherds) and was promising God's restoration through a true shepherd (David)
This passage calls the exiles to trust in God's active care and the coming of the Messiah who will shepherd the people
The covenant of peace is restored through the one shepherd (David) who will be God's representative

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'David', the contrast between shepherds and God's action, and the connection to Christ.
tips: In this context, 'David' refers to the promised Messiah (the anointed king) who will be God's shepherd, not the historical king David
The shepherds are the corrupt religious leaders of Israel who have been neglecting the people (v.3), which is a critique of the exiles' current leadership
The phrase 'I will search for My sheep' (v.10) is a promise of God's active intervention in the midst of exile

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God's search for the lost to your life this week?
tips: Identify one person in your life who feels lost or neglected and reach out to them as God has reached out to His sheep
Pray for God to search your heart for those who are 'scattered' (unreached) and bring them back
Practice being a shepherd: bind the injured (v.15) and seek the lost (v.10) in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's search for His sheep and the promise of a shepherd.
tips: Thank God that He is the Good Shepherd who seeks the lost and will restore His people
Ask God to help you be a shepherd who seeks the lost and binds the injured
Pray for the exiles in Babylon (the current church) to be restored by the one shepherd (David)

questions.title: Read Aloud

tips: Notice the phrase 'blood shall pursue you' appears twice in the passage (Ezekiel 35:5 and 6)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of condemnation and desolation

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is judged, WHAT God commands, WHERE this judgment occurs, and WHY Edom is being judged.
tips: Include Edom (Mount Seir) as the target of judgment
Note that God's command is for Edom to be made desolate and the blood of the slain to pursue them
Explain the reason: Edom's perpetual enmity and coveting of Israel's land during Israel's calamity

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the blood motif (Ezekiel 35:5-6), the total destruction of Mount Seir (Ezekiel 35:7), or Edom's claim to Israel's land (Ezekiel 35:8-9).
tips: The blood motif: A powerful image of divine judgment that is both personal and inevitable for Edom
The total destruction: Shows the severity of God's judgment on a nation that has been rebellious
Edom's claim: Highlights the historical enmity and the sin of coveting Israel's land without God's permission

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about the judgment on Mount Seir?
tips: Edom's hatred for Israel was a pattern of sin that God would judge
This was a warning to the exiles that even their enemies (Edom) would face God's judgment
The theological significance: God's justice is impartial and He will bring judgment on all who oppose Him and His people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The identity of Mount Seir, the meaning of 'blood shall pursue you', or Edom's claim to Israel's land.
tips: Mount Seir: Historically, it was the territory of Edom (a nation in the south of Israel) and the exiles in Babylon might not have known the geography
'Blood shall pursue you': This means the consequences of Edom's sin (the blood of the slain) will follow them, and it's a sign of God's judgment that will be devastating
Edom's claim: Edom had historically coveted the land of Israel (as a neighbor), but the phrase 'LORD was there' emphasizes that God was the sovereign of that land and Edom had no right to take it

questions.title: Application

Think about how you can avoid taking what doesn't belong to you (like spiritual resources)
Practice 'not coveting' by being generous and sharing with others

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His judgment on Edom and ask for the strength to not covet others' possessions.
tips: Thank God for His justice in bringing judgment on those who are enemies of His people
Pray for the courage to not covet others' land (spiritual and physical)
Ask God to help you love your neighbors and not take what doesn't belong to you

Describe God's purpose to restore His holy name that was profaned (v17)

questions.title: Best Bit

The promise of God's Spirit within (v27) provides ongoing relationship and guidance

questions.title: Main Point

tips: God's restoration is not for Israel's benefit alone but to restore His holy name (v17)

This restoration demonstrates God's faithfulness and the need for spiritual renewal through Him

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'cleansing' from uncleanness, the new heart, or the Spirit within?
tips: 'Uncleanness' (v22) refers to sin and idolatry, not just moral impurity
The 'heart of stone' (v26) is a metaphor for hardened, unresponsive hearts due to sin
The 'new heart' (v25) is a divine transformation that the exiles must receive through God's action

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of being cleansed and having a new heart in your life this week?
tips: Identify one area where you feel 'unclean' (sin or idolatry) and ask God to cleanse it
Pray for a new heart that desires to follow God's will (v25)
Seek the Spirit of God to help you live in obedience (v27)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His restoration and ask for the cleansing and new heart.
tips: Thank God that He is restoring His people from exile
Pray for the Spirit to transform your heart and lead you to righteousness
Ask God to use you to restore His name in the world

tips: Notice the phrase 'dry bones' appears multiple times (v.3, v.10) emphasizing desolation
Pay attention to the sound of rattling (v.10) as a sign of divine action
The repeated phrase 'I will cause breath to enter you' (v.11) shows God's active intervention

questions.title: Summary

tips: Include the three-part process: God commands, Ezekiel prophesies, and the bones come to life
Note that the bones represent the entire house of Israel (v.12)
The valley symbolizes the desolation of the exiles in Babylon

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the prophecy to the bones (v.11), the sound of rattling (v.10), or the bones standing as an army (v.13)?
tips: The command 'O dry bones, hear the word of the LORD' (v.11) is a direct call to the exiles to listen to God's promise
The sound of rattling (v.10) is a powerful image of God's work happening in the midst of desolation
The transformation from dry bones to an army (v.13) shows the restoration of Israel as a mighty nation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this passage about the valley of dry bones?
tips: The exiles were in a state of spiritual and physical death (exile) but God would restore them through His Spirit
This passage shows that God's promise of restoration is not conditional on human effort but on His sovereign action
The valley of dry bones is a symbol of the house of Israel being dead in sin and God's promise to bring them to life

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of 'dry bones', the role of 'breath', or the connection to the exiles?
tips: Dry bones symbolize the spiritual deadness of the exiles (not physical death but a state of desolation)
'Breath' in this context represents the Holy Spirit (v.11) or life (as opposed to the dead state)
The passage does not refer to a physical resurrection but a spiritual one: God's Spirit brings life to the dead in sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does this passage apply to your life? Consider: What area of your life feels 'dry' (spiritually dead) and how can you trust God to bring life to it this week?
tips: Think about a relationship, habit, or spiritual practice that has become 'dry' (like the bones)
Like the bones, you may feel disconnected from God but God promises to bring life through His Spirit
Pray for the Holy Spirit to 'cause breath' (life) to enter your dry areas

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the promise of resurrection and ask for His Spirit to bring life to your dry areas.
tips: Thank God that He is the resurrection and life (John 11:25) and that He brings life to the dead
Pray for courage to trust God's promise in your dry areas (spiritual, relational, or physical)
Ask God to help you become an 'army' of His people through His Spirit

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the chambers' (v.1, v.4) to emphasize the sacredness
Pay attention to the description of the holy chambers (v.10) where the priests eat the most holy offerings
The phrase 'holy garments' (v.14) appears twice and is a key detail for the priests

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is described, WHAT the chambers are for, WHERE they are located, and WHY they are significant to the priests.
tips: The chambers are built with specific dimensions (100 cubits long, 50 cubits wide) and three stories of galleries
The holy chambers on the north and south are where the priests eat the most holy offerings (grain, sin, guilt)
The priests must lay their holy garments in the Holy Place before entering the chambers

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the dimensions of the chambers (v.1-2), the holy chambers (v.10), or the requirement for holy garments (v.14).
tips: The detail about the holy chambers being the only ones where the priests eat the most holy offerings (v.10) shows the extreme sanctity of the space
The requirement that priests must lay their holy garments in the Holy Place (v.14) emphasizes the need for purity and separation
The fact that the upper chambers are narrower (v.2) might indicate that the most important tasks (like handling the most holy offerings) are done in the lower chambers

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about the sacredness of the priestly work and the temple through this vision of the chambers?
tips: Ezekiel is reminding the exiles that the temple and its sacred spaces are still real and holy, even in exile (the vision is a promise of restoration)
The vision shows that the priests must maintain strict boundaries (holy garments, holy chambers) to handle the most holy offerings, which is a sign of God's covenant with Israel
This passage also points to the future when Christ, as the ultimate High Priest, will enter the true holy place (heaven) and offer Himself as the perfect sacrifice

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The dimensions of the chambers? Why the chambers are described in detail? The concept of 'holy garments'? The role of the priests in the chambers?
tips: The cubit measurements (e.g., 100 cubits long) are symbolic of God's care for the temple, but they might be confusing without historical context
The term 'most holy offerings' (v.10) refers to specific types of sacrifices that the priests handle in the inner court, which the exiles in Babylon might not have experienced

The requirement that priests must lay their holy garments in the Holy Place (v.14) is a command that emphasizes the separation between the common and the holy, which might be hard to apply in daily li

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the concept of holy boundaries and the need for purity in your life this week?
tips: Consider an area where you are using your 'holy garments' (your life) without the necessary purity (e.g., your words, actions) and how to prepare for the 'holy place' of God's presence
Pray for the strength to keep your life separate from the unclean (like the 'outer court') when you are handling important matters (like relationships or decisions)
Make a list of the 'holy garments' you have that need to be laid in the Holy Place (e.g., your time, your prayers) before you go into a situation that requires sacred handling

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for God's guidance in maintaining holy boundaries in your life, as the priests did in the chambers.
tips: Thank God that He provides the holy garments (your life) to be used in the sacred spaces of His presence
Ask for the courage to lay your holy garments (your current life) in the Holy Place before entering the areas of your life that require handling the most holy offerings
Pray that you will be like the priests who entered the holy chambers with pure hearts, and not leave the holy place without laying the garments

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'holy district' (v.1, v.2, v.10)
Pay attention to the specific cubit measurements as a sign of divine order
The emotional tone shifts from instruction to a call for justice (v.25)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO (the Lord) is allotting the land, WHAT (the division into specific sections), WHERE (the land of Israel), and WHY (to establish a holy space for God's presence and for the people to live in justice).
tips: Include the holy district (25,000 x 20,000 cubits)
Note the sanctuary section (500 x 500 cubits) for the priests
Mention the priest section (25,000 x 10,000 cubits) and the Levite section (25,000 x 10,000 cubits)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the holy district (v.1-2), the sanctuary for the priests (v.3-4), or the call for justice (v.25)?
tips: The holy district as a divine space for God's presence (v.1-2) - this is a radical idea that God's presence is the center of the land
The specific measurements (cubits) show God's precision in His plan for the land
The closing command: 'Put away violence and oppression, and execute justice and righteousness' (v.25) is a direct call to the exiles to stop injustice

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon through this passage?
tips: Ezekiel is telling the exiles that God's presence (the holy district) is the foundation of the land, and that the division of the land is a sign of God's covenant with His people
The call for justice (v.25) is a direct response to the injustice they have experienced in Babylon
This passage is a promise that God will restore the land and the people when they obey His commands

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The measurements? Why a holy district? How does this relate to the current exile?

questions.title: Application

tips: Identify one area where you have been part of injustice (e.g., gossip, unfairness) and take steps to correct it
Pray for the strength to be just in your relationships this week
Remember that God's presence (the holy district) is with us, so we can be a community of justice

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the call to justice (v.25) and the hope of God's presence in the land
tips: Thank God for His promise to provide a holy space for His presence in our lives
Ask for the courage to be just in our communities and in our families
Pray for the exiles in Babylon (the church today) to live without violence and oppression

tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the gate of the inner court that faces east' (v1)

Listen for the rhythm of the gate opening: shut on six days, open on Sabbath and new moon (v1)

questions.title: Summary

tips: The prince's ritual entry and offering on Sabbath (v2-4)
The people's worship at the gate on Sabbaths and new moons (v5)
The specific sacrifice: six lambs and one ram (v4)

questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the gate's opening pattern (v1), the prince's sacrifice (v4), or the gate movement for feasts (v10).

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Ezekiel trying to communicate to exiles in Babylon about the proper order of worship and the role of the prince (representing the community leader) in the temple?

The prince (community leader) must lead in worship without disrupting the temple's work

questions.title: Difficulties

tips: The use of cubits (a unit of measurement) might be confusing because it's not a standard unit in modern times; note that the entire city is 18,000 cubits in circumference
The concept of a 'holy district' (25,000 cubits) for Judah might be confusing because it's larger than the other tribal portions; this reflects God's special care for Judah as the tribe that leads
The name 'The LORD Is There' (Yahweh Shammah) is a title that emphasizes God's presence, which might be challenging to grasp without the context of the exile
